title: Risk Identification & Analysis
description: Master risk identification techniques and prioritization using Probability × Impact Matrix for effective risk management.
objectives: Select appropriate risk identification technique based on team dynamics (Brainstorming, Delphi, SWOT, Assumptions Analysis)
Categorize risks using Risk Breakdown Structure: Technical, External, Organizational, Project Management
Apply Probability × Impact Matrix to prioritize risks and calculate Expected Monetary Value (EMV)
Determine when to escalate risks vs manage at project level based on authority and impact

screens.headline: 34 Risks Identified for $4.2M International Expansion

visual.description: Risk heatmap showing 34 risks across 3 markets (Mexico, Toronto, Vancouver). Most clustered in yellow/green zones, but 5 red risks could derail the project.

dialogue.text: We can't analyze all 34 risks deeply—limited time and budget. Which 5 could kill this project? How do we identify the critical ones?

screens.learningHook: Risk identification isn't just listing risks—it's finding the RIGHT technique to uncover hidden risks, categorizing them for ownership, and prioritizing based on P × I. Get this wrong: risks become issues. Get this right: proactive mitigation saves the project.

screens.title: Risk Identification & Prioritization
screens.instructions: Help Alex choose the right identification technique, categorize risks, prioritize using EMV, and decide when to escalate.

scenarios.title: Which Identification Technique?
description: Planning session for Mexico market risks
Carlos (Operations) dominates discussions, dismisses others' concerns
Taylor (Tech) has critical insights but hesitant to speak up
Maria (Mexico expert) is remote, 2-hour time difference (can't attend live brainstorming)

questions.question: Which risk identification technique should Alex use?

feedback.correct: Perfect! Delphi Technique overcomes team dynamics: Anonymous rounds prevent Carlos from dominating, allow Taylor to contribute freely, and include Maria remotely (asynchronous). Delphi builds consensus without group pressure.
feedback.incorrect: Brainstorming fails when Carlos dominates, Taylor won't speak up, and Maria is excluded remotely. Delphi Technique uses anonymous expert rounds to overcome these dynamics.

questions.question: Using Risk Breakdown Structure (RBS), how should Alex categorize this risk?

options.text: External Risk (market/regulatory/environmental factors outside project control)

feedback.correct: Exactly! Currency fluctuation is External Risk—market factor outside project control. Jordan owns relationship with finance for hedging strategies.
feedback.incorrect: Currency is an external market factor, not technical, organizational, or PM-controlled. External risks are outside project control but impact the project.

scenarios.title: How to Prioritize (P × I Matrix)?
description: Calculate Expected Monetary Value (EMV = Probability × Impact):

questions.question: Which risk should Alex prioritize for mitigation (excluding escalated risks)?

feedback.correct: Excellent! Currency risk has highest EMV within Alex's authority ($420K). EMV-based prioritization ensures limited mitigation budget goes to highest-impact risk first.
feedback.incorrect: Currency fluctuation has $420K EMV—the highest within Alex's authority. Prioritize by EMV to allocate resources to highest-impact risks.

scenarios.title: When to Escalate?
description: Regulatory risk: Mexico telecom regulations may change (60% probability)
Mitigation options: (1) Lobby regulators ($120K, uncertain), (2) Redesign ($500K, delays 4 months), (3) Accept risk
Alex's mitigation budget authority: $100K per risk

options.text: Escalate to Elena (CFO/Sponsor) for organizational decision

feedback.correct: Perfect! Risk exceeds Alex's mitigation authority ($120K > $100K), threatens project objectives (4-month delay), and requires organizational decision (lobbying regulators needs executive support). Elena has authority and organizational leverage.
feedback.incorrect: This risk exceeds Alex's $100K authority, threatens project timeline (4-month delay), and requires executive-level decisions (lobbying regulators). Escalate to Elena who has organizational leverage.

techniques.name: Brainstorming
techniques.useWhen: Equal power dynamics, live access to all SMEs, tight timeline
techniques.avoidWhen: Dominant personalities, remote team members, controversial topics

techniques.name: Delphi Technique
techniques.useWhen: Unequal power dynamics, remote/distributed team, need unbiased input

techniques.name: SWOT Analysis
techniques.useWhen: High-level strategic risks, new market entry, organizational change

techniques.name: Assumptions Analysis
techniques.useWhen: Many project assumptions, complex dependencies, innovative approach

categories.name: Technical Risks
categories.examples: Integration failure, performance issues, technology obsolescence

categories.name: External Risks
categories.examples: Currency fluctuation, regulatory changes, supplier bankruptcy

categories.name: Organizational Risks
categories.examples: Staffing shortage, budget cuts, priority shifts

categories.name: Project Management Risks
categories.examples: Scope creep, poor estimates, stakeholder misalignment

content.insight: Clear ownership → Clear accountability → Faster mitigation response

content.definition: EMV = Probability × Impact. Use P × I Matrix to prioritize limited resources.

zones.name: High P × Low I OR Low P × High I (Yellow zone)

content.prioritization: Highest EMV = highest priority (allocate mitigation budget here first)

escalateWhen: Risk mitigation exceeds PM's authority level
dontEscalateWhen: Risk is manageable at project level

high.text: Perfect! You understood that Delphi overcomes team dynamics, currency is external risk, EMV prioritizes resources, and escalation is for risks beyond PM authority. This is expert-level risk management.

medium.text: Good grasp of risk identification, but review one area: matching technique to team dynamics, or understanding when to escalate vs handle at project level.

low.text: Risk management requires systematic thinking. Review the decision framework: technique selection, RBS categorization, EMV calculation, and escalation criteria.

screens.title: Tokyo Market Expansion - Virtual Team Risk Identification
screens.context: Savory is expanding to Tokyo ($2.5M investment). Team is 100% virtual across 4 time zones: Yuki Tanaka (Tokyo, 13-hour difference), Hans Schmidt (Europe, 6-hour difference), Alex Chen (Pacific), Sarah Johnson (East Coast, 3-hour difference). Cultural factors: Yuki hesitant to contradict seniors, Hans very direct, language barriers exist.

questions.question: Which risk identification technique should Alex use for Tokyo expansion?

feedback.correct: Correct! Delphi Technique is anonymous, asynchronous, and overcomes cultural barriers, time zones, and language challenges.
feedback.incorrect: Delphi Technique is best—anonymous expert rounds overcome cultural barriers (Yuki can contribute without contradicting), time zones (asynchronous), and language barriers (written responses).

questions.question: Select reasons WHY Delphi is best for this scenario:

items.label: Overcomes cultural barriers
items.match: Yuki contributes without contradicting seniors publicly

items.label: Handles language barriers
items.match: Written responses give Yuki time to compose thoughts

items.label: Includes critical SME
items.match: Anonymous input ensures Tokyo expertise is captured

screens.title: Risk Identification Mastery
screens.summary: Risk identification is PROACTIVE—identify BEFORE they occur using RIGHT technique, categorize using RBS for clear ownership, prioritize with P × I Matrix (EMV-based), and escalate when exceeds authority.
takeaways: Select technique based on team dynamics: Delphi (dominant personalities/remote), Brainstorming (equal power/live), SWOT (strategic), Assumptions (hidden risks)
Categorize using RBS for clear ownership: Technical (Tech Lead), External (Finance/Legal), Organizational (Ops/HR), PM (Project Manager)
Prioritize using P × I Matrix: Calculate EMV (Probability × Impact), High×High = act now, Low×Low = monitor
Escalate when: Exceeds authority, threatens objectives, requires organizational decision, affects multiple projects
